linkTarget.anchoringText: Violating the constant productivity index assumption of the model makes it underperform. In the case of tight reservoirs, applying the CM can be particularly challenging because wells may be stimulated (e.g., fracturing, acid wash/squeezing) frequently, which changes their productivity index. Thus, choosing a time interval (time window), t0 < t < tmax, to perform connectivity analysis without violating this core assumption becomes tricky (Fig. 1) for large areas containing many wells

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Timeline of a sample area containing 6 wells chosen from the East Pembina Field. Trying to find a long time period with no well interventions for CM analysis is challenging

formatted-caption.caption-text: Timeline of a sample area containing 6 wells chosen from the East Pembina Field. Trying to find a long time period with no well interventions for CM analysis is challenging

linkTarget.anchoringText: Performing an IWC evaluation over a window area (Figure 2) where there is a flux imbalance however raises a problem, because the CMP is based on material balance. Hence, when the total rate of injectors is significantly different from the total rate of producers, we should add a term to the model to account for the imbalance.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Schematic well pattern showing a sample window and flux imbalance represented with a pseudo well

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic well pattern showing a sample window and flux imbalance represented with a pseudo well

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 3 summarizes the general algorithm of the CMP-PW.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: The logic of the CMP-PW

formatted-caption.caption-text: The logic of the CMP-PW

linkTarget.anchoringText: To test this approach, we simulated the production rates from a 5 × 4 homogeneous model with high permeability (Table 3) and BHPs constant employing a commercial simulator. The simulation is run for 299 months and the data are sampled monthly (Figure 4 and Figure 5). When we apply the CM to evaluate IWC for this case, we deliberately exclude I05, so we create an imbalance in the system before running the CM.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Case 1-1 injection rate (sampled monthly)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 1-1 injection rate (sampled monthly)

linkTarget.anchoringText: To test this approach, we simulated the production rates from a 5 × 4 homogeneous model with high permeability (Table 3) and BHPs constant employing a commercial simulator. The simulation is run for 299 months and the data are sampled monthly (Figure 4 and Figure 5). When we apply the CM to evaluate IWC for this case, we deliberately exclude I05, so we create an imbalance in the system before running the CM.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Case 1-1 production rate (sampled monthly)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 1-1 production rate (sampled monthly)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The CMP-PW successfully estimates the connectivities of I05 (Figure 6). The model accuracy (ie total simulated vs total CM-predicted production rates) is nearly perfect (R2 ≥ 0.99). The plot of the connectivities without a pseudo well vs. the connectivities with a pseudo well shows that points lie on the 1:1 line (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Case 1-1 Left figure: CMP-PW values (λ, shown with a line indicating the direction and the magnitude of connectivity) from the model with the pseudo well (I05). Right figure: The pseudo well is placed in the center of the map where only producers are shown

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 1-1 Left figure: CMP-PW values (λ, shown with a line indicating the direction and the magnitude of connectivity) from the model with the pseudo well (I05). Right figure: The pseudo well is placed in the center of the map where only producers are shown

linkTarget.anchoringText: The CMP-PW successfully estimates the connectivities of I05 (Figure 6). The model accuracy (ie total simulated vs total CM-predicted production rates) is nearly perfect (R2 ≥ 0.99). The plot of the connectivities without a pseudo well vs. the connectivities with a pseudo well shows that points lie on the 1:1 line (Figure 7).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Now we run the model with I05 and without providing the production rate of P04. The model identified the connectivity estimates of P04 with good accuracy, and the rate prediction accuracy is very good (R2 > 0.99, Figure 8). The connectivites from the case P04 excluded agree well with the case where all wells are included (Figure 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Case 1-2 Left: λ maps of the model with the pseudo well (P04). Right: the pseudo well connectivities are shown with bar chart

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 1-2 Left: λ maps of the model with the pseudo well (P04). Right: the pseudo well connectivities are shown with bar chart

linkTarget.anchoringText: Now we run the model with I05 and without providing the production rate of P04. The model identified the connectivity estimates of P04 with good accuracy, and the rate prediction accuracy is very good (R2 > 0.99, Figure 8). The connectivites from the case P04 excluded agree well with the case where all wells are included (Figure 9).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Case 2-1 connectivitiy values when P04 is excluded vs. the case with P04 included

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 2-1 connectivitiy values when P04 is excluded vs. the case with P04 included

linkTarget.anchoringText: We now test the model with the simulated production rates from a 5 × 4 nearly-homogeneous low permeability model with constant BHPs (Table 4,Figure 10). The simulation is run for 299 months and the data are sampled every 3 months (Figure 11 and Figure 12). Again we create an artificial imbalance by excluding the injector I05.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Case 2 5 × 4 semi-homogeneous model with producers stimulated (-2 skin); production and injection wells are denoted by P and I, respectively

linkTarget.anchoringText: We now test the model with the simulated production rates from a 5 × 4 nearly-homogeneous low permeability model with constant BHPs (Table 4,Figure 10). linkTarget.anchoringText: The estimated connectivities of I05 in the low permeability model are similar to the corresponding connectivities from the other corner injectors (Figure 13, within 14%). The model accuracy (ie total simulated vs total CM-predicted production rates) is still very high (R2 ≥ 0.99, Figure 14). When compared to the conventional case results (Figs 7 and Figure 9), the points lie along the 1:1 line with slightly larger variation (Figure 15).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The estimated connectivities of I05 in the low permeability model are similar to the corresponding connectivities from the other corner injectors (Figure 13, within 14%). The model accuracy (ie total simulated vs total CM-predicted production rates) is still very high (R2 ≥ 0.99, Figure 14). When compared to the conventional case results (Figs 7 and Figure 9), the points lie along the 1:1 line with slightly larger variation (Figure 15).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The estimated connectivities of I05 in the low permeability model are similar to the corresponding connectivities from the other corner injectors (Figure 13, within 14%). The model accuracy (ie total simulated vs total CM-predicted production rates) is still very high (R2 ≥ 0.99, Figure 14). When compared to the conventional case results (Figs 7 and Figure 9), the points lie along the 1:1 line with slightly larger variation (Figure 15).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Case 2-1 connectivities from the case with I05 excluded vs. connectivities from the case I05 included – low permeability model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 2-1 connectivities from the case with I05 excluded vs. connectivities from the case I05 included – low permeability model

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the case when I05 is not included in the CM, the history match (the simulated vs predicted production rates) using the CMP is poor (Figure 16-a). On the other hand, we get a very good match employing the CMP-PW (Figure 16-b).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Case 2-1 history match plots from the CMP (a) and the CMP-PW(b) – I05 not in the model a. CMP b. CMP-PW

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 2-1 history match plots from the CMP (a) and the CMP-PW(b) – I05 not in the model a. CMP b. CMP-PW

linkTarget.anchoringText: Here we ran the model for the more realistic case where both a producer (P04) and an injector (I05) are removed from the CMP-PW model. The model estimated the connectivities with reasonable accuracy (Figure 17). The pseudo well is determined to be an injector, which strongly supports P03. This is as we would expect, because in the real case P03 derived substantial support from the removed I05 . The history match accuracy, R2 > 0.98 (Figure 18). We found that the direct connectivities deviate from the all-wells-included case values with errors up to 24% (Figure 19).

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Case 2-2 λ maps of the model with the pseudo well (P04). Additionally, the pseudo well connectivities are shown with column chart

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 2-2 λ maps of the model with the pseudo well (P04). Additionally, the pseudo well connectivities are shown with column chart

linkTarget.anchoringText: Here we ran the model for the more realistic case where both a producer (P04) and an injector (I05) are removed from the CMP-PW model. The model estimated the connectivities with reasonable accuracy (Figure 17). The pseudo well is determined to be an injector, which strongly supports P03. This is as we would expect, because in the real case P03 derived substantial support from the removed I05 . The history match accuracy, R2 > 0.98 (Figure 18). We found that the direct connectivities deviate from the all-wells-included case values with errors up to 24% (Figure 19).

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: CM-predicted total rate vs measured total rate (R2 > 0.98) – P04 and I05 removed from the model

formatted-caption.caption-text: CM-predicted total rate vs measured total rate (R2 > 0.98) – P04 and I05 removed from the model

linkTarget.anchoringText: Here we ran the model for the more realistic case where both a producer (P04) and an injector (I05) are removed from the CMP-PW model. The model estimated the connectivities with reasonable accuracy (Figure 17). The pseudo well is determined to be an injector, which strongly supports P03. This is as we would expect, because in the real case P03 derived substantial support from the removed I05 . The history match accuracy, R2 > 0.98 (Figure 18). We found that the direct connectivities deviate from the all-wells-included case values with errors up to 24% (Figure 19).

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Connectivities from the case P04 and I05 removed vs. connectivities from the case all wells included – low permeability model

formatted-caption.caption-text: Connectivities from the case P04 and I05 removed vs. connectivities from the case all wells included – low permeability model

linkTarget.anchoringText: In a balanced injection/production case, the CMP-PW model can accommodate a reasonable range of fluid-rock system compressibilities caused by a local injection volume imbalance. To demonstrate this, we added a barrier between I01 and P01 in the semi-homogeneous 5 × 4 model (Figure 20). In this low permeability model, adding the barrier creates a local imbalance in that portion of the model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Case 3 5 × 4 semi-homogeneous model with an impermeable barrier between I01 and P01

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 3 5 × 4 semi-homogeneous model with an impermeable barrier between I01 and P01

linkTarget.anchoringText: Plots of APW-producer vs τproducer show that pseudo well connectivity increases with an increasing time constant for 8*10-6 1/psi ≤ Ct ≤ 1*10-5 1/psi(Figure 21). Within the specific compressibility range, we observe the relation between APW-producer vs Tproducer appears and the slope of the relation decreases as the system becomes more compressible.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Case 3 λPW-producer vs τproducer plots for different system compressibilities (ct ’s)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 3 λPW-producer vs τproducer plots for different system compressibilities (ct ’s)

linkTarget.anchoringText: In a balanced system, for the applicable range of compressibility, the CMP-PW pseudo well accounting for the fluid left in the low permeability model distributes it to the producers with preference given to the wells with longer time constants (e.g., P02 and P01). Sample injection allocation factors are shown with the connectivity map for the case with ct = 8*10-6 1/psi (Figure 22).

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Case 3 λ map of the model with ct = 8*10–6 1/psi

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 3 λ map of the model with ct = 8*10–6 1/psi

linkTarget.anchoringText: To illustrate this, we use the same 5 × 4 semi-homogeneous model for testing used in Case 2. For this case, P01 has a shut-in time of 15 months, and the CMP-PW predicted production rates better match the simulated rates than the comseg-CM (Table 5). The CMP-PW results are less affected by the long shut-in (Figure 23).

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Case 4 CMP-PW estimated λs with P01 shut-in are in good agreement with the λs obtained without the shut-in condition

formatted-caption.caption-text: Case 4 CMP-PW estimated λs with P01 shut-in are in good agreement with the λs obtained without the shut-in condition

linkTarget.anchoringText: On the other hand, the results from the CMP-PW reveals that the heterogeneity in τ’s is obvious and detectable. To show that, we used a 1 × 4 heterogeneous model (Figure 24) which has the same properties with the previous models except has curved relative permeability curves (Figure 25). Near wellbore regions of producers are enhanced. The flow rates are sampled for every 3 months up to 135 months (Figure 26).

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: 1 × 4 heterogeneous model with a low permeable barrier between I01 and P04

formatted-caption.caption-text: 1 × 4 heterogeneous model with a low permeable barrier between I01 and P04

linkTarget.anchoringText: On the other hand, the results from the CMP-PW reveals that the heterogeneity in τ’s is obvious and detectable. To show that, we used a 1 × 4 heterogeneous model (Figure 24) which has the same properties with the previous models except has curved relative permeability curves (Figure 25). Near wellbore regions of producers are enhanced. The flow rates are sampled for every 3 months up to 135 months (Figure 26).

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Relative permeability curves

formatted-caption.caption-text: Relative permeability curves

linkTarget.anchoringText: On the other hand, the results from the CMP-PW reveals that the heterogeneity in τ’s is obvious and detectable. To show that, we used a 1 × 4 heterogeneous model (Figure 24) which has the same properties with the previous models except has curved relative permeability curves (Figure 25). Near wellbore regions of producers are enhanced. The flow rates are sampled for every 3 months up to 135 months (Figure 26).

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Injection rate – I01 (sampled every 3 months)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Injection rate – I01 (sampled every 3 months)

linkTarget.anchoringText: We ran the model for the porosities of 7 and 9 percent and for the case with 7 percent porosity we tested the estimate stability by running the CM 15 times (Figure 27 and Figure 28). The standard deviations of estimates are very low, which reveals that the λs and τs do not vary significantly for every run. τs from the both models are reasonable and as expected, showing that P04 gets the least benefit from the injector. However, when it comes to the interpretation of the τs, the results from the models differ.

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: λs from the CM and the CMP-PW and their standard deviations (σ) for 15 runs – ϕ = 7%

formatted-caption.caption-text: λs from the CM and the CMP-PW and their standard deviations (σ) for 15 runs – ϕ = 7%

linkTarget.anchoringText: We ran the model for the porosities of 7 and 9 percent and for the case with 7 percent porosity we tested the estimate stability by running the CM 15 times (Figure 27 and Figure 28). The standard deviations of estimates are very low, which reveals that the λs and τs do not vary significantly for every run. τs from the both models are reasonable and as expected, showing that P04 gets the least benefit from the injector. However, when it comes to the interpretation of the τs, the results from the models differ.

image-wrap.label: Figure 28
image-wrap.caption: τs from the CM and the CMP-PW and their standard deviations (σ) for 15 runs – ϕ = 7%

formatted-caption.caption-text: τs from the CM and the CMP-PW and their standard deviations (σ) for 15 runs – ϕ = 7%

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the porosity increases, we observe that the ordinary CM can detect the effect of the low permeable barrier (Figure 29). But it fails to determine the difference in τs of the left 3 producers, where the CMP-PW does. We have also tested this case with high permeability, which gives identical results (Figure 30). The reason of P02 is larger than the s of P01 and P03 is due to the pore volume controlled by P02. Since P04 is blocked with the barrier, the pressure disturbance affects P02 with the largest control volume (Figure 31).

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: λs and τs from the CM with/without pseudo well – ϕ = 9%

formatted-caption.caption-text: λs and τs from the CM with/without pseudo well – ϕ = 9%

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the porosity increases, we observe that the ordinary CM can detect the effect of the low permeable barrier (Figure 29). But it fails to determine the difference in τs of the left 3 producers, where the CMP-PW does. We have also tested this case with high permeability, which gives identical results (Figure 30). The reason of P02 is larger than the s of P01 and P03 is due to the pore volume controlled by P02. Since P04 is blocked with the barrier, the pressure disturbance affects P02 with the largest control volume (Figure 31).

image-wrap.label: Figure 30
image-wrap.caption: τs from the CM with/without pseudo well – ϕ =- 9%, k = 100 md

formatted-caption.caption-text: τs from the CM with/without pseudo well – ϕ =- 9%, k = 100 md

linkTarget.anchoringText: As the porosity increases, we observe that the ordinary CM can detect the effect of the low permeable barrier (Figure 29). But it fails to determine the difference in τs of the left 3 producers, where the CMP-PW does. We have also tested this case with high permeability, which gives identical results (Figure 30). The reason of P02 is larger than the s of P01 and P03 is due to the pore volume controlled by P02. Since P04 is blocked with the barrier, the pressure disturbance affects P02 with the largest control volume (Figure 31).

image-wrap.label: Figure 31
image-wrap.caption: Pressure map of the 1 × 4 model (warm color – high pressure, cold color – low pressure)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure map of the 1 × 4 model (warm color – high pressure, cold color – low pressure)

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this work, we used the CM-PW to evaluate interwell connectivity in two areas from the East Pembina Field (Figure 32). The field was under primary depletion until 1967, when waterflooding began. It produces 37° API oil and the average permeability of the producing zone is about 0.7 md (IHS Accumap, 2014).

image-wrap.label: Figure 32
image-wrap.caption: East Pembina field – conglomerate thickness map (edited from Krause et al. 1994); contours are in meters and orange colored regions are the chosen window areas

formatted-caption.caption-text: East Pembina field – conglomerate thickness map (edited from Krause et al. 1994); contours are in meters and orange colored regions are the chosen window areas

linkTarget.bib:
Krause et al. 1994)
F. F. Krause , H. N.Collins, D. A.Nelson, S. D.Machemer, P. R.French (1987). Multiscale Anatomy of a Reservoir: Geological Characterization of Pembina-Cardium Pool, West-Central Alberta, Canada . The American Association of Petroleum Geologists Bulletin , Volume 71, No.10, October 1987, Pages 12331260.

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the first window area (Figure 33), there are 4 producers and one injector. We have chosen three time windows to study the effects of well treatments on interwell connectivity (Figure 34). We obtained a very good match between CMP-PW predicted and measured rates for all the three windows (Table 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 33
image-wrap.caption: Window I62

formatted-caption.caption-text: Window I62

linkTarget.anchoringText: In the first window area (Figure 33), there are 4 producers and one injector. We have chosen three time windows to study the effects of well treatments on interwell connectivity (Figure 34). We obtained a very good match between CMP-PW predicted and measured rates for all the three windows (Table 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 34
image-wrap.caption: Window I62 well treatment timeline. (I62 and P219 were intermittently suspended)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Window I62 well treatment timeline. (I62 and P219 were intermittently suspended)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The analysis of the first time window shows that the normalized connectivities between well pairs I62-P224 and I62-P219 are large (Figure 35). Since the pseudo well connectivity is directed towards the conglomerate bearing zone in the east, we infer that the conglomerate bearing zone contributes to the connectivities in this window, especially to the production of P219 and P184.

image-wrap.label: Figure 35
image-wrap.caption: Window I62 – the connectivity map where P224 and P219 are fractured (1st time window)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Window I62 – the connectivity map where P224 and P219 are fractured (1st time window)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Core data from unfractured wells P225 and P184 also suggest the presence of conglomerate in the east, since the flow capacity (permeability-thickness product, kh) of P184 is 2 ½ times that of well P225. A plot of λ’ vs kmaxh shows the well P184 having higher kmaxh than P225 possesses a strong positive connection with the injector whereas P225 has a negative λ’ (Figure 36).

image-wrap.label: Figure 36
image-wrap.caption: λ’ vs kmaxh chart of the initially unfractured wells P184 and P225

formatted-caption.caption-text: λ’ vs kmaxh chart of the initially unfractured wells P184 and P225

linkTarget.anchoringText: P225 is the only well having λ’ < 0. It appears the operator may have identified this issue. The well was acid squeezed twice and fractured with 8.5 tons of 10/20 sand after the first window (AER Database). Connectivity analysis in the second time window (Figure 37) indicates the connectivity of P225 increased by 0.16 (i.e., Δλ’ = λ’win2 – λ’ win1 = 0.16), and the connectivity of I62 with other producers either decreased (I62 – P184) or remained the same (I62 – P219).

image-wrap.label: Figure 37
image-wrap.caption: Window I62 – the connectivity map after acid squeezing and fracturing P225 (2nd window time)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Window I62 – the connectivity map after acid squeezing and fracturing P225 (2nd window time)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The 2nd window period IWC analysis reveals that, after the well treatments at other producers, injection support from I62 towards P184 diminished. Perhaps the operator was also aware of this problem. In 1986, P184 was fractured with 27 tons of 20/40 sand (AER Database). The connectivities in the window area are again changed (Figure 38).

image-wrap.label: Figure 38
image-wrap.caption: Window I62 – the connectivity map after fracturing P184 (3rd window time)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Window I62 – the connectivity map after fracturing P184 (3rd window time)

linkTarget.anchoringText: A plot of Δ λ’ vs proppant tonnage for the treatments of wells P225 and P184 shows a direct proportion (Figure 39), where we have added the point at the origin on the basis that zero proppant should leave the connectivity unchanged.

image-wrap.label: Figure 39
image-wrap.caption: Δλ’ vs proppant tonnage

formatted-caption.caption-text: Δλ’ vs proppant tonnage

linkTarget.anchoringText: Prior to the first time window, all 4 producers were fractured (Figure 40). The CMP-PW analysis (Figure 41) reveals that the largest connectivities are oriented in the NE-SW direction, which is consistent with the direction of maximum horizontal principal stress in the region (Bell et al., 1994).

image-wrap.label: Figure 40
image-wrap.caption: Timeline of the Window I40-I37-I18

formatted-caption.caption-text: Timeline of the Window I40-I37-I18

linkTarget.anchoringText: Prior to the first time window, all 4 producers were fractured (Figure 40). The CMP-PW analysis (Figure 41) reveals that the largest connectivities are oriented in the NE-SW direction, which is consistent with the direction of maximum horizontal principal stress in the region (Bell et al., 1994).

image-wrap.label: Figure 41
image-wrap.caption: Window I40-I37-I18 – connectivity map of the first time window (The direction of larger horizontal principal stress in the region is NE-SW.)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Window I40-I37-I18 – connectivity map of the first time window (The direction of larger horizontal principal stress in the region is NE-SW.)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Before the second time window, P145 was fractured again, although the reasons are unclear because the CMP-PW analysis suggests this well was supported by both I37 and I40. After the P145 refracture, connectivity with I37 and I40 decreased and P127 is the only well having positive normalized connectivity (Figure 42).

image-wrap.label: Figure 42
image-wrap.caption: Window I40-I37-I18 – the connectivity map of the second time window (P128 abandoned, P145 fractured)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Window I40-I37-I18 – the connectivity map of the second time window (P128 abandoned, P145 fractured)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The second period analysis shows that P145 does not benefit from the nearby injectors. P145 was fractured for the third time prior to the third window period (Figure 40). Re-fracturing P145 does not appear to have been effective (Figure 43); I40 decreased connectivity with the surrounding producers.

image-wrap.label: Figure 43
image-wrap.caption: Window I40-I37-I18 – the connectivity map of the third time window (P145 fractured)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Window I40-I37-I18 – the connectivity map of the third time window (P145 fractured)

linkTarget.anchoringText: It appears that injector induced fractures controlled the connectivity distribution of I40 during window 1 (Figure 44). Having the steepest slope of the plot and the largest connectivities oriented in the direction of larger horizontal stress in the first time window suggests there may be an injector induced fracture. When the slope of the plot decreases in the second time window, we observe that the connection with P145 was lost.

image-wrap.label: Figure 44
image-wrap.caption: Cumulative injected volume with respect to time for injection well I40 (1, 2 and 3 show the corresponding time windows)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative injected volume with respect to time for injection well I40 (1, 2 and 3 show the corresponding time windows)
